awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Creating an Upper Division Additive Manufacturing Course and Laboratory For Enhancing Undergraduate Research and Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
American economic and social theorists have predicted that Additive Manufacturing (AM) heralds the beginning of the Third Industrial Revolution, succeeding the production line assembly that has dominated manufacturing since the late 19th century. AM, also known as 3D printing, refers to a process used to create a three-dimensional artifact by printing successive layers of material under computer control. The significant drop in price of 3D printers over the last decade has made them relatively common in undergraduate engineering labs, thereby opening up the opportunity to provide students with extended first-hand experience of AM. The goal of the project is to help K-12 students and engineering undergraduates learn about AM so that they are better prepared for the renaissance in U.S. manufacturing.  Student learning will be supported by the labs, projects, course materials, and a textbook on AM that will be developed during this project. The institutions involved are Texas Tech University (TTU), a university with high research activity (RU/H), California State University, Northridge, a non-PhD-granting institution that is both an HSI (Hispanic Serving Institution) and an AANAPISI (Asian American Native American Pacific Islander Serving Institution), and Kansas State University (KSU), both an EPSCoR and an RU/H institution. 

Through creation of the AM course, the following goals will be met: (1) the development of intellectually rigorous course materials (e.g., textbook, lab manual, lecture notes) that will be publicly accessible via hard copy and a virtual classroom website; (2) the conduct of important educational research on the impact of the new AM curricula on changes in student attitudes and self-efficacy in STEM, the results of which will be published in engineering and education journals; (3) the development of simplified 3D printing projects for K-12 students and Maker Space users. Outreach by engineering undergraduates to K-12 students through one-on-one mentoring relationships will help to build the K-12 STEM pipeline by creating excitement and interest in engineering as a career.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, three universities (Texas Tech University, Kansas State University, and California State University, Northridge) have collaborated to (I) create a class on additive manufacturing (also known as 3D printing) and (II) conduct and assess educational research concerning the effects of this class on undergraduate engineering students and K-12 students.

Since the project started in September 2017, the primary investigators at the lead institution (Texas Tech University) have completed the major pedagogical and research tasks proposed in the project including developing a new upper-division undergraduate class called 3D Printing and Additive Manufacturing - Fundamentals and Practices (Outcome 1) and then transferring that class into a popular and permanent elective course (IE4358) in the Industrial, Manufacturing, and Systems Engineering Department (Outcome 2). The class has been offered to students five times from Spring 2018 to Spring 2022. We have also developed and refined intellectually rigorous course materials that include a textbook, lab manuals, lecture notes, lab guidance, final project manual, quizzes and exams, etc. to be used in the course that are publicly accessible (Outcome 3). During the question-solving project-based lab sections, the students gained capabilities in finding the solution and designing the workpiece for specific applications, making judgments for different additive manufacturing processes for the applications, finding and solving the issues during the additive manufacturing processes, etc., which significantly helped their future career development in the manufacturing companies. Additionally, we have constructed an online classroom with recorded lectures and virtual labs that were particularly useful during the COVID-19 pandemic (Outcome 4). Upon request, several virtual labs were disseminated to other universities for similar courses.

Our research results about the effects of this class on participating undergraduates and the K-12 students they mentored are encouraging. To measure growth, we developed and conducted yearly assessments of objective subject knowledge growth and subjective student self-assessments of how the course affected their skills as an engineer and desire to stay in the profession (Outcome 5).  Knowledge growth was particularly pronounced in female students and students of color, supporting the hypothesis that this team-based class targets underserved populations in engineering. Our results have been published in four ASEE annual conference proceedings.

We also conducted and assessed multiple outreach activities that enabled the undergraduates to practice their mentorship and public speaking skills (Outcome 6). Additive manufacturing workshops for local high school students were hosted twice by the PI and his students (both graduate and undergraduate). Middle school and local community college lab tours were also offered by the PI and his students. We scaled our assessments from Outcome 5 above to be able to measure growth in knowledge and attitudes towards engineering in the middle and high school students.  Knowledge growth was small and positive, but answers about attitudes towards engineering were highly encouraging, with many students remarking on their surprise that they understood the purpose of additive manufacturing more following their visit and that their interest had deepened.

The project provided opportunities for the PI or Co-PI to disseminate results by attending four ASEE annual conferences (three face-to-face and one virtual conference) and visiting the other two participating institutions (Outcome 7). The PIs delivered three poster presentations and one virtual presentation as well as published four conference papers at the ASEE conferences to disseminate the results.

The project provided opportunities for enrichment for graduate and undergraduate students in both engineering and sociology (Outcome 8). Specifically, four engineering graduate students participated in class and lab instructions as teaching assistants. Several undergraduate students offered presentations in high school workshops and talks during the additive manufacturing lab visit. Sociology graduate students participated in the assessment of the learning outcomes via data collection and analysis of research. Three graduate students helped conduct the surveys and then collated the data for analysis. Two graduate students aided in yearly analysis and another student collated all four years of data and used it for his master’s thesis work.
